questions.question_text:
A customer is deploying a new Horizon View Pool which will support workstations deployed using older third-party zero clients. The older zero clients will be used to access a 3D modeling application.
Which protocol should the pool use?

discussion.content: C - PCoIP, because of Zero Clients
Definitely "C". very few new Zero clients offer Blast except latest in the last 2 years.
Should be C. Older, prior to 2019, zero clients, only supported PCoIP. Keyword here is zero vs thin

BCE are out. Only AD makes sence.
A I have done but really bad option. D is again possible but bad option. the other 3 not really possible
Assuming Centralised deployment for Physical and Virtual both bcoz the of the statement line "not individual VDI desktops". Going with A and D as my option.
I'm also in camp A and D... but C would technically work, too.
For me it's A,D taking into account this part of the question: "The applications must be assigned to users and not individual VDI desktops".

I feel BD is the proper answer. Using GPO to deploy the application cancels the "central location" of the Thinapp package. This question suggests you'll use Streaming Execution mode PP 17 from this link 
https://www.vmware.com/content/dam/digitalmarketing/vmware/en/pdf/VMware-ThinApp-Reviewers-Guide.pdf

comments.content: Ok, I was stick on streaming execution mode and re-reading the guide I don't see why you couldn't use a GPO. Also good catch that you cannot assign users in the console so 'B' goes away. AD it is

For me, B is not possible because you can't assign a thinapp package throuth the console to a user ("must be assigned to users"). Page 23 in the documentation (pool or desktop)
https://www.vmware.com/content/dam/digitalmarketing/vmware/en/pdf/VMware-ThinApp-Reviewers-Guide.pdf
I think it's AD

choices.D: Using thinreg.exe, add ThinApp packages registration and use the PermittedGroups option for the identified user groups.
choices.C: Copy the Thinapped MSI to an App Volumes App Stack and assign the application via Active Directory.
choices.B: In the Horizon Administration console, add the network share with the ThinApp packages. Entitle ThinApp packages using the Horizon Administration console.
choices.A: Using Microsoft Active Directory and Group Policy Objects, deploy the ThinApp MSI file upon login of the users.
choices.E: Implement VMware Identity Manager, install the VMware Identity Manager for Windows on all VDI desktops and entitle the ThinApp packages using VMware Identity Manager.

questions.question_text:
An architect is asked to review a company's plans to implement ThinApp packaged applications to its non-persistent Virtual Desktop Infrastructure (VDI). The applications must be assigned to users and not individual VDI desktops. All ThinApp packages are already available on a network share.
Which two options can the architect recommend to meet requirements? (Choose two.)

choices.E: Capture Windows applications as a Thin App.

comments.content: Agree. Furthermore, you can configure the number of spare (powered on) machines in the instant clone pool.

discussion.content:
B&D
ICs with UEM/DEM will be more efficient. I would also suggest an extra 100-200 extra CCU licenses instead of just 500 to allow some overlap of shifts. This would be far more cost effective than the additional hardware needed for full clone desktops.

comments.content: I would say B & D because a Full Clone would require way more administrative overhead additionally, a call center is categorized as a Task user, requiring the most minimal desktop possible. Although I follow your thought pattern of having the full clone vm's already ready and available but in this case you are only looking at 200 instant clones that would need to be spun up for the third shift, which would happen basically at 1.5 seconds per vm as the second shift is logging off. With that said, doing the calculation it should spin up the 200 vm's in 5 minutes total time

discussion.content:
I guess C, D.
According to https://blogs.vmware.com/euc/2016/02/horizon-7-view-instant-clone-technology-linked-clone-just-in-time-desktop.html, Instant Clone with 1,000 VMs needs 25 minutes.
How about 500 VMs for this case ?

questions.question_text:
A customer is looking to implement Horizon View Windows desktops for a 500-seat call center operating under these conditions:
✑ Three 8-hout shifts
✑ First and second shifts are 100% staffed
✑ Third shift operates with reduced staffing of only 200 representatives
Management is frustrated by the lack of productivity that occurs during shift changeover. Logoff and logon processes take in excess of 5 minutes.
The customer has asked an architect to recommend the most cost-effective configuration that provides the shortest possible amount of downtime between shifts.
Which two should the architect choose? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Sorry BD, only the SQL servers are compatible/supported

comments.content:
BD, AppVolumes required SQL Server Microsoft
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-App-Volumes/2.15/com.vmware.appvolumes.install.doc/GUID-5C1CFB43-1311-4E0D-B0E2-9E45165A5353.html

All the answers are correct which is B&D, main reason is because the question is a little tricky. It states a company selected one database instance. By default of AppVolumes & Composer has to run only on SQL, while vCenter could run on Oracle so the answer has to be only SQL.

discussion.content: as you know both Oracle 11 and Sql 2014 supported already and regarding your artical (the question didn't mention the version of the Horizon )

AD is the answer, as of Horizon 7 Oracle 12c and above is the only supported Oracle DB

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Horizon-7/7.0/com.vmware.horizon-view.installation.doc/GUID-5B2266B8-EA3C-4F49-BABB-2D0B91DE6C1D.html

questions.question_text:
In a local design, a company selected one database instance to be shared by Horizon View Composer database, vCenter external database, and Horizon
AppVolumes database. The design must provide High Availability for all databases.
Which two database server options should be selected during physical design creation? (Choose two.)

DRAG DROP -
Match the customer issue with a VMware Horizon View solution.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

comments.content: This is the way I put it before I press the show answer button

discussion.content:
I think this answer is wrong. should not it be the following order?
Legacy app with internet explorer dependency -> thinapp
Complicated logon script for drive mapping -> UEM
Misuse of licensed software -> App Volumes
Install Applications on stateless desktop -> Writables volumes

comments.content:
I would suggest karnyk's answer is correct.
Use App Volumes to control misuse of licensed software by only assigning the software deployed via App Volumes to licensed users.
Install of Applications on stateless desktops suggests User Installed Apps, which requires a Writable Volume vs. who gets access to licensed software

discussion.content:
Legacy app with internet explorer dependency -> thinapp (That is what Thinapp was designed for)
Complicated logon script for drive mapping -> UEM (UEM LOGON/LOGOFF script)
Misuse of licensed software -> Writables volumes (Software license got to be kept somewhere permanent)
Install Applications on stateless desktop -> App Volumes (This is what Appvol does)
I think that the answer wrong here, UEM should be with "logon script...
